title: Computers and Coding Foundations
description: Build strong understanding of what computers do and how programs work. Learn to think logically, plan step-by-step instructions, and express creativity through code.
capstoneProject: A complete Scratch game or story with animations, scoring, and user interaction.
keyTakeaways: Confidence with computers, ability to think algorithmically, and an early appreciation for computational creativity.
learningGoals: Students build a strong understanding of what computers do and how programs work. They learn to think logically, plan step-by-step instructions, and express creativity through code. By the end of the course, they can design simple interactive games and animations while using correct coding concepts such as loops, conditionals, and variables.
sessionOutline: Introduction to computers and how programs follow instructions
Understanding algorithms through real-life examples and puzzles
Exploring the Scratch interface and creating a first animated scene
Working with motion, looks, and events to make sprites move and react
Using loops and conditionals to build interactive behaviours
Introducing variables to keep scores and control character actions
Building and testing a simple game using learned concepts
Debugging and improving programs systematically
Introduction to Blockly and comparing block-based environments
Designing an independent project idea and planning its logic
Creating and refining the project
Presenting the finished program and reflecting on problem-solving strategies

title: Introduction to Google Office
description: Master Google Docs, Sheets, Slides, and Drive. Develop digital literacy and collaboration skills for school and work.
techStack: Google Docs, Sheets, Slides, Drive, Chrome
capstoneProject: A digital portfolio containing one formatted document, a functional spreadsheet, and a slide presentation.
keyTakeaways: Digital literacy, collaboration skills, and confidence in online productivity tools.
learningGoals: Students become fluent with productivity tools used in schools and workplaces. They learn to create, edit, format, and share documents, spreadsheets, and presentations while developing responsible digital habits.
sessionOutline: Navigating operating systems and browsers; saving and organising files
Introduction to Google Drive and cloud storage
Creating and formatting documents in Google Docs
Inserting images, tables, and hyperlinks for polished reports
Collaboration and real-time editing with shared documents
Basics of Google Sheets: entering data, using formulas, and charts
Using Sheets to organise information such as class scores or expenses
Building a visual presentation with Google Slides
Incorporating text, images, and animations for clear storytelling
Understanding online safety, privacy, and responsible sharing
Mini-project creation combining Docs, Sheets, and Slides
Presentation and peer feedback

title: Using Excel and Google Sheets for Problem Solving
description: Explore data organization and analysis with formulas, charts, and real-world applications like budgets and surveys.
capstoneProject: A practical spreadsheet that collects, analyses, and visualises real data, such as a class survey or personal finance tracker.
keyTakeaways: Foundational data literacy, logical thinking, and the ability to use spreadsheets as analytical tools.
learningGoals: Students explore how spreadsheets organise and analyse information. They learn formulas, chart creation, and data-driven reasoning using engaging, age-appropriate problems such as budgets, scorecards, and surveys.
sessionOutline: Introduction to spreadsheets, cells, and data types
Entering and formatting data for readability
Using basic formulas for addition, subtraction, and averages
Understanding absolute and relative references
Sorting and filtering information to conclude
Creating and customising charts to visualise data
Real-world application: tracking a class event or a small budget
Exploring conditional formatting to highlight trends
Collaborative editing and sharing via Google Sheets
Introduction to simple data validation and protection
Designing an independent spreadsheet project
Presentation and interpretation of results

title: Introduction to AI
description: Learn AI concepts through Teachable Machine and Scratch. Build interactive games that respond to gestures and images.
techStack: Teachable Machine, Scratch with ML extensions
capstoneProject: An interactive Scratch or Teachable Machine game that responds to gestures, voices, or images.
keyTakeaways: Conceptual understanding of AI, creativity in applying technology, and awareness of ethical considerations.
learningGoals: Students learn what artificial intelligence means in simple, concrete terms. They explore how computers recognise patterns and make predictions by training small models that react to sound, image, or motion inputs.
sessionOutline: Understanding AI through examples from daily life
Concept of learning from data and how computers identify patterns
Introduction to Teachable Machine and image classification
Training models and testing accuracy
Improving results by collecting better examples
Integrating trained models into Scratch projects
Building an interactive AI-driven game or animation
Exploring ethical questions such as bias and fairness
Refining projects and adding creativity
Sharing and discussing projects in class
Presenting the final game and explaining how AI was used
Reflecting on future possibilities of AI and personal interests

title: Introduction to Python
description: Master Python fundamentals with clear, correct code. Build text-based applications and develop logical thinking skills.
capstoneProject: A text-based application such as a quiz, calculator, or word game demonstrating user interaction and basic control flow.
keyTakeaways: Solid programming fundamentals, logical thinking, and confidence to tackle independent coding tasks.
learningGoals: Students learn to write clear, correct Python code, understand how programs are structured, and solve small real-world problems. The focus is on reasoning, not memorisation, so learners build a foundation that supports any future language or discipline.
sessionOutline: Setting up Python and understanding how programs run
Variables, data types, and input/output
Conditional statements and decision-making
Loops and iteration for repetitive tasks
Lists and strings — storing and manipulating collections of data
Functions — writing reusable and organised code
File handling — reading and writing text files
Debugging and common error patterns
Mini-project planning and algorithm design
Building and testing the project
Adding features and improving readability
Project presentation and reflection on logic skills

title: Programming in C and C++
description: Learn low-level programming, memory management, and efficient code. Build console applications with structured design.
techStack: C and C++ Compilers (Code::Blocks, Visual Studio Code)
capstoneProject: A console-based utility, such as a student record system or menu-driven calculator, showing a structured and modular design.
keyTakeaways: Understanding of how computers execute code, efficient programming habits, and a strong foundation for advanced languages.
learningGoals: Students gain insight into low-level program structure, memory, and performance. They learn how C and C++ code is compiled and executed, and how to write efficient, well-commented programs that handle input, processing, and output.
sessionOutline: Understanding compilation and the program execution process
Syntax, data types, variables, and operators
Conditional logic and loops
Functions and scope of variables
Arrays and strings — working with collections of data
Structures and basic pointers for memory management
File input/output and simple data storage
Introduction to problem decomposition and modular design
Debugging and common errors in compiled languages
Planning and building a final project
Code review and documentation
Presentation and reflection

title: Algorithmic Thinking and Version Control
description: Think like engineers with flowcharts, Git, and GitHub. Master collaborative development and professional workflows.
techStack: Flowchart tools (Lucidchart or draw.io), Git, GitHub
capstoneProject: A group GitHub repository containing a well-documented logical project with branch histories and collaboration evidence.
keyTakeaways: Strong grasp of algorithmic structure and practical experience using industry-standard version control.
learningGoals: Students learn to think like engineers: break problems into steps, represent logic visually, and collaborate using professional version-control tools. The course bridges logical reasoning and real-world software practice.
sessionOutline: What is an algorithm, and why does structure matter?
Flowcharts and pseudocode — visual logic
Translating logic into real problems, such as sorting and searching
Introduction to Git — repositories, commits, and local workflow
Working with branches and merges
Pushing projects to GitHub and collaborating online
Resolving merge conflicts and using commit messages effectively
Structuring projects and maintaining a readable history
Group exercise — collaborative repository for a shared project
Documentation using README files and basic Markdown
Final project creation and upload
Presentation and code review

title: Object-Oriented Programming Concepts
description: Move from procedural to object-oriented design. Learn classes, inheritance, and polymorphism for modular programs.
techStack: Python or C++ (OOP focus), IDE of choice
capstoneProject: A small software system, such as a library manager or inventory tracker, illustrating objects, inheritance, and polymorphism.
keyTakeaways: Understanding of OOP design principles, code reusability, and professional organisation of projects.
learningGoals: Students move from procedural thinking to object-oriented design, learning how to model real-world entities through classes and objects. They develop programs that are modular, reusable, and easier to maintain.
sessionOutline: Review of procedural concepts and the need for OOP
Understanding classes, objects, and attributes
Defining methods and encapsulation of data
Constructors, destructors, and lifecycle management
Inheritance and code reuse
Polymorphism and method overriding
Access specifiers and data security
Composition vs inheritance — choosing the right structure
Error handling and exceptions in OOP
Building a multi-class project from concept to implementation
Documentation and testing
Presentation and code walk-through

title: Basics of Data Science
description: Collect, clean, analyze, and visualize data with Python, Pandas, and Matplotlib. Develop critical thinking through real datasets.
capstoneProject: Analyse a publicly available dataset (such as sports scores or weather records) and present findings through graphs and a written summary.
keyTakeaways: Confidence with data handling, understanding of basic analytics, and a foundation for advanced ML or statistics courses.
learningGoals: Students learn to collect, clean, analyse, and visualise data. The course develops numerical reasoning and critical thinking through hands-on projects using real datasets.
sessionOutline: Understanding what data science is and its applications
Loading datasets and exploring structure and types
Cleaning and pre-processing data
Computing descriptive statistics and basic summary measures
Visualising trends with Matplotlib and Pandas charts
Working with categorical data and grouping
Identifying correlations and simple patterns
Introduction to CSV files and basic data import/export
Mini analysis project design and planning
Performing analysis and visualisation
Preparing findings for presentation
Presenting projects and reflecting on insights

title: Applied Math with Python or R
description: See mathematics come alive through computation. Apply algebra, geometry, and statistics using code visualization.
techStack: Python with NumPy and Matplotlib or R with ggplot2
capstoneProject: A simulation or data visualisation demonstrating a mathematical principle, for example, a random walk model or geometric pattern exploration.
keyTakeaways: Improved mathematical intuition, ability to express quantitative ideas through code, and preparation for data-driven STEM fields.
learningGoals: Students see mathematics come alive through computation. They apply algebra, geometry, probability, and statistics concepts using code to visualise and experiment with real phenomena.
sessionOutline: Connecting mathematical concepts to programming
Using Python or R for basic calculations and symbolic representation
Graphing linear and quadratic functions
Exploring geometry through coordinate transformations
Probability simulation using random numbers
Statistical analysis of sample data
Creating visualisations that explain mathematical ideas
Modelling real-world situations such as population growth or motion
Designing a mathematical investigation project
Writing and testing the simulation code
Interpreting and communicating results
Presentation and peer feedback

title: Python for Real-World Applications
description: Apply Python beyond basics to solve practical problems. Automate tasks, web scraping, and API integration.
techStack: Python, standard libraries (os, datetime, requests), IDE of choice
capstoneProject: Automate a real-world task such as gathering weather data, managing files, or generating reports. Include proper documentation and reusable functions.
keyTakeaways: Practical Python proficiency, ability to write reliable scripts, and experience applying programming to real problems.
learningGoals: Students learn to apply Python beyond basic exercises to solve practical problems, automate tasks, and integrate with real-world systems. They gain experience designing scripts for productivity, data collection, and system interactions.
sessionOutline: Recap of Python basics and control structures
File handling and manipulation (reading/writing files, CSV/JSON)
Automating routine tasks with scripts
Web scraping with libraries like requests and BeautifulSoup
Working with APIs and JSON data
Exception handling and logging for robust scripts
Modular programming and reusable function libraries
Introduction to virtual environments and package management
Debugging, testing, and documenting scripts
Capstone project design session: selecting a real-world problem
Implementation, testing, and refinement
Presentation of automated solution and code walk-through

title: Data Structures and Algorithms
description: Master efficient computation and algorithmic thinking. Learn data structures, sorting, searching, and optimization.
techStack: Python or C++, IDE, visual algorithm tools (optional)
capstoneProject: Design and implement a mini library of data structures and algorithms that can solve a complex problem, such as a pathfinding simulation or a text processing system.
keyTakeaways: Ability to analyse and implement core data structures and algorithms, understand trade-offs, and optimise computational efficiency.
learningGoals: Students understand the foundations of efficient computation, algorithmic thinking, and memory/data management. They learn to choose appropriate data structures and implement algorithms for performance-critical applications.
sessionOutline: Review of complexity analysis (Big O notation)
Arrays, linked lists, stacks, and queues
Trees (binary, AVL) and graph representations
Hashing and hash tables
Sorting algorithms (merge, quick, heap)
Searching algorithms (binary search, BFS, DFS)
Recursion and dynamic programming
Algorithm optimisation techniques
Implementing standard data structures from scratch
Applying algorithms to solve real-world problems
Code review and debugging complex algorithms
Final exam and reflection on algorithm design

title: Introduction to Databases (DBMS)
description: Structure, query, and manipulate data in relational databases. Learn SQL, normalization, and database design.
capstoneProject: Create a small relational database (e.g., inventory system or student records) with a front-end query interface, demonstrating CRUD operations and relationships.
keyTakeaways: Ability to design, implement, and query relational databases and integrate them into software applications.
learningGoals: Students learn to structure, query, and manipulate data in relational databases, understanding the principles of database design, normalisation, and transactions.
sessionOutline: Database fundamentals: tables, rows, columns
SQL queries: SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE
Filtering, sorting, and aggregating data
Joins, subqueries, and set operations
Database normalisation and relationships
Indexing and performance optimisation
Transactions and constraints for data integrity
Connecting Python scripts to a database
Designing a simple relational database for a project
Testing, querying, and reporting from the database
Capstone project presentation
Final assessment and portfolio review

title: Introduction to Machine Learning
description: Learn ML foundations from preprocessing to model evaluation. Explore supervised and unsupervised learning with real projects.
techStack: Python, scikit-learn, Pandas, Matplotlib, Google Colab
capstoneProject: Predict outcomes from a real dataset (e.g., housing prices, student performance, or stock trends), including data cleaning, model training, and evaluation.
keyTakeaways: Foundational understanding of ML pipelines, model selection, and practical application of algorithms to real datasets.
learningGoals: Students learn the foundations of machine learning, from preprocessing data to training and evaluating models. They explore supervised and unsupervised learning through practical projects.
sessionOutline: Introduction to ML concepts: supervised vs unsupervised learning
Data preprocessing: cleaning, normalisation, feature engineering
Regression models: linear and polynomial regression
Classification models: k-NN, decision trees, logistic regression
Evaluation metrics: accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score
Clustering algorithms: k-means and hierarchical clustering
Model training, validation, and cross-validation
Overfitting, underfitting, and regularisation techniques
Mini ML project: from dataset to model evaluation
Communicating insights with visualisations
Advanced topics: neural networks introduction
Capstone project presentation and peer review

title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
description: Explore AI concepts, problem-solving strategies, and intelligent agent design. Create AI applications and simulations.
techStack: Python, basic AI libraries (e.g., OpenAI API, Gym), optional TensorFlow/PyTorch introduction
capstoneProject: Develop a simple AI agent (e.g., maze solver, tic-tac-toe player, or chatbot) demonstrating reasoning, decision-making, and evaluation.
keyTakeaways: Understanding of AI principles, search and decision-making strategies, and hands-on AI implementation.
learningGoals: Students explore AI concepts, problem-solving strategies, and intelligent agent design. They learn how to simulate decision-making and create simple AI applications.
sessionOutline: AI concepts: agents, environments, and problem spaces
Search algorithms: BFS, DFS, A*, heuristic search
Game AI and decision trees
Knowledge representation and reasoning basics
Simple natural language processing
Reinforcement learning introduction
Ethical considerations in AI
Mini project: AI agent in a game environment
Testing, debugging, and performance analysis
Presenting the AI solution and explaining design choices
Advanced AI applications
Final project showcase and reflection

title: Introduction to R for Data Science
description: Master R for statistical computing and data visualization. Learn tidyverse, ggplot2, and exploratory data analysis.
capstoneProject: Analyse a real-world dataset in R, generate visualisations, perform basic statistical analysis, and produce a report summarising findings.
keyTakeaways: Competence in R for data manipulation, visualisation, and preliminary statistical analysis, providing a strong foundation for data science.
learningGoals: Students gain proficiency in R for statistical computing, data visualisation, and exploratory data analysis. They learn how to process data efficiently and communicate insights effectively.
sessionOutline: Basics of R programming and RStudio environment
Data types, vectors, matrices, and data frames
Data manipulation with dplyr
Visualisation using ggplot2 and basic plots
Summary statistics and descriptive analytics
Working with real datasets: CSV, Excel, APIs
Introduction to statistical tests and hypothesis testing
Mini analysis project: data exploration and visualisation
Reporting findings with reproducible RMarkdown
Peer review and project discussion
Advanced visualisation techniques
Final project presentation and portfolio

title: Math Support Track (All Levels)
description: Tailored math support across all curriculum levels. Reinforce algebra, calculus, probability, and linear algebra concepts.
capstoneProject: Comprehensive math assessment and targeted improvement plan with regular progress tracking.
keyTakeaways: Strengthened mathematical foundation, improved quantitative reasoning, and confidence in applying math in programming and data science.
learningGoals: Provide tailored support in mathematical concepts required across the curriculum, reinforcing problem-solving, symbolic reasoning, and computational applications.
sessionOutline: Assessment of existing math skills
Targeted reinforcement of algebra, calculus, probability, and linear algebra
Problem-solving workshops and guided exercises
Regular quizzes and progress tracking
Peer tutoring and collaborative exercises
Integration with programming and data science projects
